2_1KcPohxmuqiNShTaAzJZLndm5aWtBZLuJn.body:
> [cgm616](#comment_5_1KcPohxmuqiNShTaAzJZLndm5aWtBZLuJn): Problem with ZeroSearch is that you need to know what you're looking for, you can't just browse and find something. Yes, they are similar but ZeroIndex would be a way to easily find content you didn't know you wanted.

ZeroSearch is a good idea but it needs a way to search for media formats like JPG, TIF, PNG, GIF and BMP for images and AVI, WMV, MP4, MOV and MPEG for video. It also needs a way to display them like Google and Yahoo does. Both Google and Yahoo have a video search and a image search and ZeroSearch needs something similar. 

ZeroIndex is also a good idea though. It would be nice if ZeroSearch and ZeroIndex could be used together. ZeroIndex could be used to index everything and then you could use ZeroSearch to search through the ZeroIndex folders. 
Example -  You index a blog about nature on ZeroIndex and give it tags like nature, blog and landscapes, then people can use ZeroSearch and type in nature or landscape and ZeroSearch searches through ZeroIndex and brings up anything with those tags.

> [cgm616](#comment_6_1KcPohxmuqiNShTaAzJZLndm5aWtBZLuJn): Yeah, that's a good bridge between the two. I like that idea. Also, yeah, ZeroSearch needs a way to find sites, which is the thing I'm trying to fix with Zeroindex. Google is able to crawl to pages, because very rarely is a page linked nowhere. However, pages are linked nowhere a lot in ZeroNet, and there is no site crawler for it yet. That means a lot of interesting content, say about nature, seen only by the visitors to that site, and not by someone who posts nature to ZeroSearch.

I think you would have to give ZeroIndex a search box and when someone searches for a tag like nature,  you could have ZeroIndex programmed to exclude the sites you already have and only show the ones you don't have.

> [nofish](#comment_135_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): When the user.json file saved (to avoid data lost at all costs) it's done this way:
> 
> New content written to user.json-new
> Current users.json renamed to users.json-old
> user.json-new renamed to users.json
> users.json-old removed
> 
> So if you see users.json-old file it means for some reason the saving process is interrupted. I was unable to reproduce the problem, but I will keep my eye over it.

Thanks nofish

I've tried to stress the need for a CMS for the ZeroBlog to make it more user friendly for us "normals" that can't code. A lot people use CMS's and even businesses use CMS's. I'd rather hit a button to upload an image to my website instead of having to code the image into the html or CSS. With a CMS you just have to click a button to search for images to add to your post. You can even change the background color of your websites easier with a CMS instead of having to go into the CSS and change something. Wordpress has a good CMS and if ZeroBlog had one that was similar, it would attract more people to ZeroNet. Us "normals" like buttons to upload stuff and change the appearance of the pages, we don't like to code to do it. It is the coding that's scaring away some "normals".

It's ridiculously easy to start a site, but not follow up and do anything special with it unless you know how to code and/or don't mind getting messy.
> It basically results in a few well-made sites, and a ton of identical silly blogs. Which isn't really all that fun for much of anyone, haha. Gotta have more dynamic content and more active users.

Yea the cloning is easy but you can't do to much else to the blog after you clone it unless you can code. Everybody likes to give their websites a personal look and feel and on ZeroNet you can't. We need other coders to touch up the things nofish creates on ZeroNet, meaning we need coders to work on s CMS for the blog and also maybe some coders working on a way to sends files through ZeroMail like you can do with most emails.

I don't like Markdown and I really don't understand it to well either. I know a lot of forums are starting to use it. Most of us non-coders hate coding because if you get one thing wrong in the code it wont work right, so we use things like a CMS. Us non-coders don't want to constantly have to go to a file and do this  <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /> or this { position: absolute; -webkit-transform: translateX(-50%) and take a chance of getting it wrong when we could just use a CMS or Admin Panel. > It's very easy (and understandable) to think that things that don't look simple are hard, but if you look close enough, you'll start to see that it's very logical and might end up liking it.

Thanks for offering to help me but after trying to code already once, I do not want to try it again. If you want to help then please help some other coders come up with a CMS for ZeroNet.

> [kaffie](#comment_53_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): I think you're missing the point. Oracle's talking about people who normally wouldn't go out and make a website. Those millions of people who just want to click a button and have their content appear on the page. Markdown is fine, as we see people on reddit use it just fine despite having no coding experience. However, how many of those users would, say, be comfortable digging into the html and javascript of a site to customize it? Hell, even a lot of reddit moderators don't care to do that and just copy+paste important stuff they like (full themes, generators for stuff, etc).
> And back in the day with myspace we saw a similar thing happen. People visited site generators to theme their site, rather than digging into the html/js. I see ZeroNet quite similarly to how Myspace or even something like Geocities was back in the day: where everyone has their own little site customized to their taste.
> However, I do see this as an opportunity to educate people on how stuff actually works, and get them digging into code and learning about how websites work, rather than continue to rely on buttons.
> All that being said, I love markdown. It's fantastic. It should honestly be a standard.

But don't forget some of us love the buttons but hate to code. ZeroNet needs to cater to both, coders and non-coders. The non-coders can use the CMS while coders could still code what they want. I think of ZeroNet as more of a Product and not a Project. If you want the Consumer to use a product you have to cater to their needs and wants. I love what nofish has created but it does need a CMS. I believe a CMS will get more consumers, who can't code or don't want to code, to use ZeroNet.
